thread.title: Heavyweight boxer tackled man running from police and pinned him 'like a pretzel' until they caught up

author: Jacob Jarvis
title: Heavyweight boxer tackled man running from police and pinned him 'like a pretzel' until they caught up
text:

A puffed-out policeman has thanked a semi-professional boxer who spotted the officer chasing a suspect and stepped in to assist. 
Well-built pugilist Martin Kohala was out celebrating his partner’s birthday at Tarro Lounge, in Hinckley , when he saw the chase. 
The 35-year-old noticed the police officer was out of breath as he chased after “a big lad dressed in black”, and offered to help. Martin is has been boxing for years and has a heavyweight fight coming up 
Mr Kohala, who works at Triumph Motorcyles Ltd in the town, said: “I ran after him [the suspected shoplifter] like Usain Bolt. 
“I kicked his legs just before the cinema. He stumbled. 
"I followed and shouted, 'Stop'. 
“He turned on me and I took him out [tackled him]. 
“He was fighting back and shouted, ‘Let me go’. 
"I held him against the wall, pinned up like a pretzel.” Read More Melton Mowbray pork pies, Leicestershire cheese and Rutland beer under threat if US gets its way post-Brexit 
An officer from Market Bosworth police took to Facebook to explain what happened and thank Mr Kohala. 
The officer stated that Mr Kohala had looked at the man the officer was sprinting after, and asked: “Do you want him?” 
The police officer gasped, “Too right”, and Mr Kohala got running. 
The fighter is near peak fitness as he prepares for a heavyweight bout on Friday, May 11, at The Sports Connexion in Coventry. 
Despite his heroics, Mr Kohala did not stick around for appreciation afterwards. 
The Market Bosworth officer described him as being “like a dynamo” and just disappearing. 
“I said, ‘I've got a party next door and gotta dash, so you guys do what you have to, pleasure to help’, and I went back to Tarro,” Mr Kohala said. 
It is because of the athlete's quick getaway that officers thanked Mr Kohala over social media. Read More
